entry.title: A Comprehensive Guide and Test Plan for Internal Order Management in SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
Part 1: The Guide - Concepts and Configuration

This part of the guide is for Key Users and Consultants. It explains the foundational concepts and the essential configuration steps required to set up a robust Internal Order Management system.

Chapter 1: Foundations of Internal Order Management

1.1 What is an Internal Order?

Think of an Internal Order as a temporary cost collector—a flexible "bucket" or "envelope" used to plan, collect, and monitor costs (and sometimes revenues) for a specific job, event, or project. Unlike a cost center, which represents a permanent part of your organization's structure (e.g., the Marketing Department), an internal order has a finite lifecycle. It's created for a specific purpose and eventually closed.

Common uses include:

  • Monitoring overhead costs: Tracking the expenses of a specific internal project, like an office renovation or an IT system upgrade.
  • Capital investments: Collecting all costs related to building or purchasing a new asset (like machinery or a building) before it's officially placed into service. This is often called an "Asset under Construction" (AuC) process.
  • Event management: Tracking the costs and revenues for a trade show, marketing campaign, or company event.

1.2 Real vs. Statistical Orders

This is a crucial concept. Every internal order has a defining characteristic: it's either Real or Statistical.

  • Real Orders: These are the primary cost objects. They actually hold the costs and are settled at the end of a period to another object (like a cost center, a fixed asset, or a profitability segment). The costs temporarily "live" on the real order.
  • Statistical Orders: These are for informational and reporting purposes only. When you post a cost to a statistical order, you must also provide a real cost object, like a cost center. The cost center truly holds the cost, while the statistical order just gets a "memo" or a copy for analysis. You can't settle a statistical order because it never truly owned the costs in the first place.

Example: You want to track the total printing expenses across the entire company (the real cost is in each department's cost center), but you also want to see how much of that printing is related to the "Annual Report 2025" project. You would post the invoice to the respective department cost center (Real) and the "Annual Report 2025" statistical internal order (Statistical).

1.3 Integration with the SAP S/4HANA Universe

Internal Orders are not an isolated tool. Their power comes from deep integration across the entire SAP S/4HANA landscape.

  • Financial Accounting (FI): Direct G/L postings can be made to internal orders.
  • Materials Management (MM): Purchase orders for materials or services can be assigned to an internal order, ensuring procurement costs are tracked correctly.
  • Asset Management (AM): Investment orders are used to build Assets under Construction (AuC) and settle the final costs to a fixed asset record.
  • Sales and Distribution (SD): Costs associated with a specific sales order (e.g., for a custom engineering project) can be collected on an internal order.
  • Human Capital Management (HCM): Payroll costs can be allocated to internal orders.
  • Project System (PS): Internal orders can be used for smaller, less complex projects as an alternative to a full-blown WBS structure.

Chapter 2: Master Data Configuration

This chapter details the configuration settings that define the behavior and appearance of your internal orders. These settings are typically performed by consultants in the SAP system.

2.1 Order Types: The Blueprint for Internal Orders

The Order Type is the most important piece of configuration. It acts as a blueprint that defines the purpose and controls for a group of similar internal orders. The provided documents listed several custom order types (Z200, Z500, Z600, etc.). In a standard S/4HANA system, we would create types that reflect business processes.

Example Standard Order Types:

  • Y100 - Overhead Orders: For general cost monitoring (e.g., internal projects, R&D).
  • Y200 - Investment Orders: For capital projects that will result in a fixed asset.
  • Y300 - Orders with Revenue: For events or projects where you expect to post both costs and revenues.
  • Y400 - Statistical Orders: For reporting and analysis purposes.

Key Configuration Settings in an Order Type:

  • Order Category: Specifies whether the order is for Overhead (01), Investment (02), Orders with Revenue (05), etc. This is a critical field that locks in certain system behaviors.
  • Settlement Profile: (See Chapter 4) Assigns the set of rules governing how the order will be settled.
  • Budget Profile: (See Chapter 3) Assigns the rules for budgeting and availability control.
  • Model Order: You can assign a template order here, so when users create a new order of this type, many fields are pre-filled.
  • Status Profile: Defines a sequence of user statuses (e.g., Created -> Approved -> Released -> Closed) to control which business transactions are allowed at each stage.

🔧 Customizing Point (Consultants):

  • Path: SPRO > Controlling > Internal Orders > Order Master Data > Define Order Types
  • Action: Create new entries for your required order types (e.g., Y100, Y200) and assign the relevant profiles.

2.2 Screen Layout and Field Selection

You don't want a user creating a simple marketing order to be bothered with fields related to asset management. The screen layout configuration allows you to control the status of every field on the internal order master data screen for each order type.

Field Statuses:

  • Hidden: The field is not visible to the user.
  • Display: The field is visible but cannot be changed.
  • Optional Entry: The user can make an entry in the field.
  • Required Entry: The user must make an entry in the field to save the order.

Let's translate the requirements from the document FPM-OR04-10v:

For an Investment Order (Type Y200):

  • Investment Reason: This field is critical for capital expenditure reporting. We make it a Required Entry.
  • Start/End of Work: These dates are essential for project tracking. They become Required Entries.
  • External Order No.: For an internal capital project, this is irrelevant. We set it to Hidden.

For an Overhead Order (Type Y100):

  • Investment Reason: Not applicable. We set it to Hidden.
  • Responsible Person: Always important for accountability. We make it a Required Entry.
  • Estimated Costs: Useful for simple planning. We make it an Optional Entry.

🔧 Customizing Point (Consultants):

  • Path: SPRO > Controlling > Internal Orders > Order Master Data > Screen Layout > Define Field Selection for Order Master Data
  • Action: Select the field group (e.g., "Investment Data") and set the status of each field (e.g., "Investment Reason") for your specific order types.

2.3 Investment Reasons

For capital investment orders, classifying the reason for the investment is vital for strategic decision-making and reporting. The system allows you to define a custom list of reasons.

Example Investment Reasons (based on FPM-OR06-10v):

  • REPL: Replacement of existing asset
  • CAPA: Capacity Increase
  • NEWP: New Product Launch
  • COST: Cost Savings Initiative
  • TECH: Technological Improvements
  • ENV: Environmental Protection

🔧 Customizing Point (Consultants):

  • Path: SPRO > Investment Management > Internal Orders as Investment Measures > Master Data > Define Investment Reason
  • Action: Create new entries for each required investment reason, giving them a code and a descriptive text.

Chapter 3: Budgeting and Availability Control

Budgeting prevents overspending and provides a baseline for measuring performance. SAP's Availability Control (AVC) is the active mechanism that enforces the budget.

3.1 Budget Profiles

A Budget Profile controls how budgeting functions for orders it's assigned to. It's a collection of settings that determine:

  • Timeframe: Can you budget by year, or only for the total project lifetime (Overall Values)?
  • Currency: Is budgeting done in the company code currency or can you use another currency?
  • Availability Control: Is AVC active, and how is it activated?

Based on the provided documents (FPM-OR05-20v), a key decision was made to activate AVC automatically.

Key Settings for a typical Investment Budget Profile (translating Z00001):

  • Timeframe: Overall and Annual Values.
  • Past/Future: Allow budgeting for 1 year in the past and 5 years in the future.
  • Currency: Allow budgeting in Object Currency.
  • Availability Control: Set to 1 - Automatic activation upon budget allocation. This means as soon as the first dollar is budgeted, the system starts checking against it.

🔧 Customizing Point (Consultants):

  • Path: SPRO > Controlling > Internal Orders > Budgeting and Availability Control > Maintain Budget Profiles
  • Action: Create a new budget profile, configure its settings, and then assign this profile to your investment order types.

3.2 Availability Control (AVC) and Tolerance Limits

Availability Control (AVC) is the system's "policeman." When a user tries to create a commitment (like a purchase order) or post an actual cost, AVC checks if enough budget is available.

Tolerance Limits define how strictly the policeman behaves. You can set up different actions for different levels of budget consumption.

Let's translate the scenario from document FPM-OR05-20v:

  • Profile: Investment Orders Budget Profile
  • Transaction Group: ++ (All transactions)
  • Action 1 (Warning): When budget consumption reaches 90%, the system will issue a warning message. The user can proceed but is alerted that the budget is nearly exhausted.
  • Action 3 (Error): When budget consumption reaches 100%, the system will issue a hard error message. The user cannot save the purchase order or posting. The transaction is blocked.

🔧 Customizing Point (Consultants):

  • Path: SPRO > Controlling > Internal Orders > Budgeting and Availability Control > Define Tolerance Limits for Availability Control
  • Action: For your budget profile, create entries for the desired transaction groups (e.g., ++ for all) and define the usage rate percentage that triggers a Warning (1), Warning with Mail (2), or Error (3).

Chapter 4: Cost Allocation and Settlement

Costs collected on a real internal order must eventually be moved to their final destination. This process is called Settlement.

4.1 Settlement Profiles

The Settlement Profile is a set of rules assigned to the order type that governs the entire settlement process.

Key Controls in a Settlement Profile:

  • Valid Receivers: What types of objects can this order be settled to? For an investment order, you would allow FXA (Fixed Asset) and CTR (Cost Center). For an overhead order, you might only allow CTR (Cost Center) and G/L (G/L Account).
  • Allocation Structure: (See 4.2) Which rule should be used to determine how costs are grouped and settled?
  • Document Type: The accounting document type (e.g., SA) used for the settlement posting.
  • Residence Time: How long should settlement documents be kept in the system before they can be archived? The documents specify 3 months.

🔧 Customizing Point (Consultants):

  • Path: SPRO > Controlling > Internal Orders > Actual Postings > Settlement > Maintain Settlement Profiles
  • Action: Create a new settlement profile (e.g., YI for Investment, YO for Overhead). Define the valid receivers and other parameters. Assign this profile to your order types.

4.2 Allocation Structures

An Allocation Structure is the heart of the settlement configuration. It specifies which costs (grouped by source cost elements) are settled using which settlement cost element.

Example Scenario (for an Investment Order):

  • Source: We collect various costs on the order:
    • External labor (cost element 410000)
    • Raw materials (cost element 510000)
    • Internal engineering hours (secondary cost element 630000)
  • Allocation Structure Y1: We create one assignment in this structure.
    • Source Cost Elements: A group containing all primary and secondary cost elements (RGLOBAL in the source docs).
    • Settlement Cost Element: When settling to a fixed asset, all these costs should be capitalized. We might use a secondary cost element like 722200 (Capitalized Costs) to track this. The system will then debit the asset and credit the order using this cost element.

🔧 Customizing Point (Consultants):

  • Path: SPRO > Controlling > Internal Orders > Actual Postings > Settlement > Maintain Allocation Structures
  • Action: Create an allocation structure (e.g., Y1). Within it, create assignments. In each assignment, specify the source cost element groups and the corresponding settlement cost element for each receiver type (e.g., asset vs. cost center).

4.3 Number Ranges for Settlement

Every time a settlement is run, the system creates a controlling document. This document needs a unique number from a predefined number range.

🔧 Customizing Point (Consultants):

  • Path: SPRO > Controlling > Internal Orders > Actual Postings > Settlement > Maintain Number Ranges for Settlement Documents
  • Action: For your controlling area, ensure that number range intervals are maintained for object CO_KABR.

Part 2: The End-to-End Process Flow in Action

This part is for all users. It provides step-by-step instructions for executing the daily, monthly, and yearly processes related to internal orders using modern SAP Fiori applications.

Chapter 5: Creating and Budgeting an Internal Order

5.1 Scenario: New Marketing Campaign

The marketing department is launching a "Summer Sale 2025" campaign. The marketing manager wants to track all associated costs, which are estimated to be $50,000. This will be a simple overhead order settled to the marketing cost center at the end of each month.

5.2 How-To: Create the Internal Order

  1. Open the Fiori App: Log in to the Fiori Launchpad and open the Manage Internal Orders app.
  2. Create New Order: Click the "Create" button.
  3. Select Order Type: Choose the appropriate order type for overhead cost tracking, for example, Y100 - Overhead Orders.
  4. Enter Master Data:
    • Description: Summer Sale 2025 Campaign
    • Company Code: Enter your company code (e.g., 1710)
    • Responsible Cost Center: Enter the Marketing Cost Center (e.g., 17101401). This is often used for default values.
    • Responsible Person: Marketing Manager
    • Estimated Costs: $50,000
  5. Define the Settlement Rule:
    • Go to the "Settlement Rule" tab.
    • Category: CTR (Cost Center)
    • Settlement Receiver: Enter the Marketing Cost Center (17101401).
    • Percentage: 100%
    • Settlement Type: PER (Periodic) - this means costs are settled each period.
  6. Save and Release:
    • Save the order. The system will assign a number.
    • Use the "Change Status" button to Release the order. Only released orders can have costs posted to them.

5.3 How-To: Assign a Budget

For orders that require strict financial control (like investment orders), you must assign a budget.

  1. Open the Fiori App: Use the enterprise search or navigate to the My Projects - Cost-based app. You can also use the classic transaction KO22 - Change Order Budget.
  2. Enter the Order Number: Enter the number of the internal order you just created.
  3. Assign Budget:
    • Enter the budget amount (e.g., $250,000 for an investment project) in the "Overall" or current year field.
  4. Save: Save the budget. Because of our configuration, Availability Control (AVC) is now active for this order.

Chapter 6: Posting Costs to an Internal Order (Integration)

Now that the order is set up, let's see how costs are collected from different business processes.

6.1 Scenario: Incurring Campaign Costs

The "Summer Sale 2025" campaign requires hiring a design firm and paying for some catering for a launch event.

6.2 MM Integration: Procuring Services

  1. Create Purchase Requisition: The marketing specialist opens the Manage Purchase Requisitions app and creates a request for "Graphic Design Services" for $15,000. On the "Account Assignment" tab, they select category F (Order) and enter the internal order number for the Summer Sale campaign.
  2. Create Purchase Order: The purchasing department converts the PR into a PO using the Manage Purchase Orders app. The account assignment to the internal order is automatically copied. This PO now represents a commitment against the order's budget.
  3. Post Service Entry Sheet / Invoice: When the design firm sends their invoice, the Accounts Payable clerk posts it using the Create Supplier Invoice Fiori app, referencing the PO. The system automatically proposes the posting to the internal order. Upon posting, the commitment is converted into an actual cost.

6.3 FI Integration: Direct G/L Posting

The catering for the launch event was paid directly.

  1. Open the Fiori App: The finance team opens the Post General Journal Entries app.
  2. Enter Posting Details:
    • G/L Account: 475000 (Events and Catering Expense)
    • Amount: $2,500
    • Cost Object: In the line item details, they enter the internal order number for the Summer Sale campaign.
  3. Post: The document is posted, and $2,500 is immediately recorded as an actual cost on the internal order.

Chapter 7: Monitoring and Reporting

Throughout the campaign's lifecycle, the marketing manager needs to monitor its financial status.

  1. Open the Fiori App: The manager opens the Internal Order - Plan/Actuals app.
  2. Enter Selection: They enter the internal order number.
  3. Analyze the Report: The report displays:
    • Plan/Budget: The initial estimated costs or formal budget.
    • Commitments: Open purchase orders that have not yet been invoiced (e.g., $15,000).
    • Actuals: Costs that have been posted (e.g., $2,500).
    • Available Amount: The budget minus commitments and actuals.

Chapter 8: Period-End Closing (Settlement)

At the end of the month, all costs collected on the Summer Sale order need to be transferred to the Marketing department's cost center.

8.1 How-To: Run Settlement

  1. Open the Fiori App: The cost controller opens the Run Settlement - Actuals app.
  2. Enter Parameters:
    • Controlling Area: A000
    • Period / Fiscal Year: The current month and year.
    • Selection Variant (Optional): You can use pre-saved variants (as described in FPM-OR08-10v) to select all "Overhead Orders" or "Investment Orders" for a specific company code.
    • Internal Order: Enter the specific order number or a range.
  3. Execution Mode:
    • First, run in Test Run mode. The system simulates the settlement and shows what postings it would make without actually doing it. This is a critical safety check.
    • Review the log for any errors.
    • If the test run is successful, uncheck the Test Run box and execute the settlement in Production Run mode.
  4. Verification:
    • The system posts a journal entry. The internal order is credited (its balance becomes zero for the period), and the receiving cost center is debited.
    • Re-run the Internal Order - Plan/Actuals report. You will see the settled amount, and the order's cumulative balance will be zero.

Part 3: Comprehensive Test Plan

This section provides practical, step-by-step test cases for users to execute in a quality assurance or training system. It solidifies understanding by applying the concepts from the guide.

Prerequisites:

  • A configured SAP S/4HANA system with the necessary organizational structure (Company Code, Controlling Area, Plant, etc.).
  • Relevant master data is available (G/L Accounts, Cost Centers, Vendors, Materials).
  • User has the required authorizations for all Fiori apps and transactions mentioned.

Test Case 1: Overhead Cost Monitoring

Objective: Validate the complete lifecycle of a simple overhead internal order, from creation to settlement. This mirrors the "E.R.D." or "Z200" type from the source documents.

Scenario: The IT department needs to track the costs of providing new laptops to the Sales team in Q4 2025. The total estimated cost is $30,000.

Step

Action

Fiori App / T-Code

Expected Result

Pass/Fail

1.1

Create an Internal Order. Type: Y100 (Overhead), Description: Sales Laptops Q4 2025, Responsible Cost Center: IT Dept Cost Center, Responsible Person: IT Manager.

Manage Internal Orders

Order is created with a unique number. The status is "Created".

 

1.2

Define the settlement rule: 100% to the Sales Dept Cost Center, Periodic (PER).

Manage Internal Orders

Settlement rule is saved.

 

1.3

Release the order.

Manage Internal Orders

Status changes to "Released". Postings are now possible.

 

1.4

Create a Purchase Order for 20 laptops from a vendor for $25,000. Account assign to the new internal order.

Manage Purchase Orders

PO is created. In the order report, this amount appears as a commitment.

 

1.5

Post a direct FI expense for software licenses for $5,000 against the order.

Post General Journal Entries

$5,000 appears as an actual cost in the order report. The total of actuals + commitments is $30,000.

 

1.6

Run the month-end settlement for the order in Test Mode.

Run Settlement - Actuals

The log shows a successful simulation, crediting the order and debiting the Sales Dept Cost Center for $5,000 (only actuals are settled). No errors.

 

1.7

Run the month-end settlement in Production Mode.

Run Settlement - Actuals

Settlement document is posted. The order report shows a settled amount of $5,000, bringing the order's current balance to zero.

 

1.8

Set the order status to "Technically Completed".

Manage Internal Orders

The status changes. No new commitments (e.g., PRs) can be created for this order.

 

Test Case 2: Capital Investment with Budget Control

Objective: Test the end-to-end process for an investment order used to build a fixed asset, including budget availability control (AVC). This mirrors the "Z600" investment type.

Scenario: The company is installing a new production machine. The total approved budget is $500,000. Costs will be collected on an investment order and settled to an Asset under Construction (AuC) monthly.

Step

Action

Fiori App / T-Code

Expected Result

Pass/Fail

2.1

Create an Asset under Construction (AuC) master record. Asset Class: 4000 (AuC - Machinery). Note the AuC number.

Create Asset

AuC master record 4000-XXXXX is created.

 

2.2

Create an Internal Order. Type: Y200 (Investment), Description: New Production Machine Line 5, Investment Reason: Capacity Increase.

Manage Internal Orders

Order is created.

 

2.3

In the order, define the settlement rule: 100% to the AuC created in step 2.1. Category: FXA, Settlement Type: PER. Release the order.

Manage Internal Orders

Settlement rule is saved, order is released.

 

2.4

Assign a budget of $500,000 to the order.

My Projects - Cost-based / KO22

Budget is saved. AVC is now active automatically.

 

2.5

Test AVC (Warning): Create a PO for the machine for $460,000 (92% of budget). Account assign to the order.

Manage Purchase Orders

A Warning message appears ("Budget is 92% exhausted"), but you can save the PO.

 

2.6

Test AVC (Error): Create another PO for consulting services for $50,000 (10% of budget). Account assign to the order.

Manage Purchase Orders

A hard Error message appears ("Budget exceeded"). You cannot save the PO.

 

2.7

Post a supplier invoice for $100,000 against the first PO.

Create Supplier Invoice

$100,000 is posted as an actual cost to the order.

 

2.8

Run the month-end settlement for the order.

Run Settlement - Actuals

The $100,000 actual cost is settled to the AuC. The order balance is zero, and the AuC now has an acquisition value of $100,000.

 

2.9

(Final Step) After the machine is complete, create the final fixed asset record (e.g., Asset 1000-YYYYY). Change the settlement rule on the order to settle 100% to this new final asset. Run settlement again.

Manage Internal Orders, Run Settlement - Actuals

The entire value from the AuC is transferred to the final asset. The final asset is now ready for depreciation.

 

Test Case 3: Sales Order Integration and Profitability

Objective: Validate the process of using an internal order to collect costs for a customer project and settle them to profitability analysis (CO-PA). This mirrors the "CSR" or "Z500" concept.

Scenario: A consulting services contract is signed with a customer. A sales order is created, and an internal order will be used to track all project costs (consultant time, travel).

Step

Action

Fiori App / T-Code

Expected Result

Pass/Fail

3.1

Create a Sales Order for a service material. In the item details (Account Assignment tab), the system should automatically create a linked internal order. Order Type: Y300 (Orders with Revenue). Note the order number.

Create Sales Orders

Sales order is created. A linked internal order is created automatically.

 

3.2

Post consultant timesheets for 40 hours against the internal order. (This can be simulated with a direct CO posting if CATS is not configured).

Manage My Timesheet / KB21N

Actual costs for the consultant's time are posted to the internal order.

 

3.3

Post a travel expense report for $1,500 against the internal order.

Post General Journal Entries

Actual costs of $1,500 are posted to the order.

 

3.4

Run Resource-Related Billing.

DP91

The system reads the costs from the internal order and creates a Debit Memo Request for billing the customer.

 

3.5

Create the customer invoice from the Debit Memo Request.

Create Billing Documents

The customer is invoiced. Revenue is posted to the Sales Order and the linked internal order.

 

3.6

Run the month-end settlement for the order. The settlement rule should automatically be set to the Profitability Segment (PSG).

Run Settlement - Actuals

All costs and revenues from the order are settled to CO-PA. The order's balance becomes zero.

 

3.7

View the profitability report for the customer/product combination.

Profitability Reports (e.g., KE30)

The report shows the revenue from the invoice and the costs from the settlement, allowing for an accurate project margin analysis.

entry.title: The Ultimate Guide to Margin Analysis (CO-PA) in SAP S/4HANA
entry.content:
Introduction: Why Profitability Analysis?

In today's competitive landscape, simply knowing if you made a profit is not enough. You need to know where you are profitable and why. Profitability Analysis (CO-PA) is the SAP module that answers these critical business questions:

  • Which of our products are the most profitable?
  • Which customers or customer groups generate the highest margins?
  • Are we more profitable in certain countries or regions?
  • What is our margin after considering the detailed cost of producing our goods?
  • How do sales variances, discounts, and overhead costs impact our bottom line?

Margin Analysis vs. Account-Based COPA

SAP S/4HANA offers two forms of Profitability Analysis. Understanding the difference is key.

  1. Account-Based COPA: This is the default and simplified approach in S/4HANA. It works by adding profitability characteristics (like customer, product) to general ledger journal entries. It is perfectly reconciled with the G/L by design but offers a less detailed breakdown of costs and revenues.
  2. Margin Analysis (This Guide's Focus): This is the classic, powerful version of CO-PA. It uses value fields to store amounts and quantities, offering a highly detailed and flexible view of profitability. Its key strength lies in its ability to break down the Cost of Goods Sold (COGS) into its original components (e.g., raw materials, labor, overhead) and to calculate anticipated or statistical values. While requiring a reconciliation step with the G/L, it provides an unparalleled level of detail for contribution margin reporting.

Global S4H CLUB Inc. has chosen Margin Analysis because they need a granular breakdown of their manufacturing costs to analyze the profitability of each product line effectively.

Chapter 1: The Foundation - Structuring Your Profitability Analysis

Before we can analyze anything, we must build the house where our data will live. This foundation is called the Operating Concern.

1.1. The Operating Concern

The Operating Concern is the highest organizational unit in Profitability Analysis. It defines the scope of your analysis, including which controlling areas and company codes will report into it, and determines the structure of the data you will analyze. All stakeholders who need a consistent view of profitability will share the same Operating Concern.

For Global S4H CLUB Inc., we will create the Operating Concern V000.

1.2. Basic Settings and Activation

Concept: You must first define the attributes of your Operating Concern, such as the currencies it will use and its fiscal calendar. Then, you activate it.

Customizing Point (For Consultants)

  • Path: SPRO > Controlling > Profitability Analysis > Structures > Define Operating Concern.
  • SAP Central Business Configuration (CBC): This is configured during the initial setup of the Finance scope items.

How-To Guide:

  1. Navigate to the "Define Operating Concern" transaction.
  2. Create a new Operating Concern, V000, with the description "Global S4H CLUB Group."
  3. Attributes Tab:
    • Fiscal Year Variant: Enter K4 (Calendar year with 4 special periods). This ensures that the CO-PA calendar aligns with the financial accounting calendar.
    • Currencies: In S/4HANA, the system automatically uses the Company Code Currency. You should also activate the Global Currency (e.g., USD or EUR) for consolidated reporting across multinational company codes.
  4. Data Structures Tab:
    • Here, you will define the characteristics and value fields (covered in the next sections).
  5. Environment Tab:
    • After defining the structure, you must Generate the Environment for the Operating Concern. This is a critical technical step that creates the necessary database tables and programs in the background.

Finally, you must assign your Controlling Area(s) to the Operating Concern.

  • Path: SPRO > Controlling > Profitability Analysis > Structures > Assign Controlling Area to Operating Concern.

1.3. Defining the Dimensions of Analysis (Characteristics)

Concept: Characteristics are the "by what" dimensions of your analysis. They answer the question, "How do we want to slice and dice our profit?" Examples include Customer, Product, Country, Salesperson, etc. S/4HANA provides many standard characteristics and allows you to create your own.

The original S4H CLUB design included many custom characteristics (WW...). We will map these to standard SAP objects where possible to follow best practices.

Standard (Fixed) Characteristics

Your Operating Concern automatically includes essential characteristics like:

  • BUKRS (Company Code)
  • ARTNR (Product)
  • KNDNR (Customer)
  • VKORG (Sales Organization)
  • WERKS (Plant)

Mapping Custom Requirements to Standard/Custom Characteristics

Let's modernize the Global S4H CLUB requirements:

Original "S4H CLUB" Field

Business Meaning

S/4HANA Best Practice Solution

How-To

WWPH1, WWPH2, WWPH3

Product Family, Type, Version

Product Hierarchy

Use the standard characteristic PRODHE which reads from the material master (MARA-PRDHA). Configure the levels of the hierarchy in SPRO.

WWCL0

Customer Typology

Customer Group

Use the standard characteristic KTOKD, which is directly read from the customer master data. No custom field is needed.

WWGP0

Country Group

Custom Characteristic

Create a new characteristic WW_CGR ("Country Group"). We will then create a derivation rule (see Chapter 2) to populate it based on the customer's country (LAND1).

WWVIG

Intra-Group Sales Code

Trading Partner

Use the standard characteristic VBUND (Trading Partner). This field is automatically populated during intercompany transactions, providing a standard way to identify and exclude this business.

Customizing Point (For Consultants)

  • Path: SPRO > Controlling > Profitability Analysis > Structures > Maintain Characteristics.
  • How-To Create WW_CGR:
    1. Go to the transaction and click "Create."
    2. Enter the name WW_CGR.
    3. Choose to create it with "User-defined characteristic."
    4. Provide a description: "Customer Country Group."
    5. Define its technical attributes: Type CHAR, Length 6.
    6. Crucially, you need to define a Check Table. This is a custom table where you will maintain the valid values (e.g., "EMEA," "NA," "APAC"). This ensures data integrity.
    7. Save and activate the characteristic.

1.4. Defining the Key Figures (Value Fields)

Concept: If characteristics are the "by what," value fields are the "what." They are the numeric fields that store your key figures—revenues, costs, quantities, discounts, etc. This is the heart of Margin Analysis.

The original S4H CLUB design contained a highly detailed list of VV... value fields, representing a granular cost breakdown. This is a classic use case and is achieved by integrating with Product Cost Planning (CO-PC).

Mapping Cost Breakdown to Value Fields

The goal is to map the Cost Component Structure (CCS) from CO-PC to the value fields in CO-PA. The CCS breaks down the standard cost of a product into meaningful categories.

Step 1: Define the Cost Component Structure

  • Path: SPRO > Controlling > Product Cost Controlling > Product Cost Planning > Basic Settings for Material Costing > Define Cost Component Structure.
  • How-To: Create a CCS named GV (Global S4H CLUB) with the following components. Each component is linked to specific G/L accounts or cost element groups.

Cost Component

Description

Original "S4H CLUB" Field

10

Plastics

VV100

20

Rubber Materials

VV101

30

Metal Materials

VV102

40

Packaging

VV103

100

Variable Labor

VV200

110

Fixed Labor

VV201

200

Variable Factory Overhead

VV401

210

Fixed Factory Overhead

VV400

...and so on for all other cost types.

...

...

Step 2: Define the Value Fields in CO-PA

  • Path: SPRO > Controlling > Profitability Analysis > Structures > Maintain Value Fields.
  • How-To: Create a value field for each key figure you want to analyze.

Value Field Name

Type

Description

VVREV

Amount

Gross Revenue

VVDISC

Amount

Sales Deductions / Discounts

VVSQTY

Quantity

Sales Quantity

VV100

Amount

Cost - Plastics

VV101

Amount

Cost - Rubber

VV102

Amount

Cost - Metals

VV103

Amount

Cost - Packaging

VV200

Amount

Cost - Variable Labor

VV201

Amount

Cost - Fixed Labor

...and so on.

...

...

After defining all characteristics and value fields, add them to your Operating Concern's data structure and regenerate the environment.

Chapter 2: The Heart of the Engine - Data Valuation and Enrichment

Now that our structure is built, we need to define the rules that will automatically populate it with rich, detailed data during business transactions. This involves two key processes: Valuation (how to calculate values like COGS) and Characteristic Derivation (how to populate our analytical dimensions).

2.1. Overview of Valuation Strategies

Margin Analysis allows you to "value" a transaction to add information that isn't directly available. For example, when you bill a customer, the billing document contains the revenue, but not the detailed cost breakdown. Valuation fills this gap. The primary methods are:

  1. Using Product Cost Estimates (This Guide's Focus): The system reads the material's standard cost estimate and uses the cost component split to populate the COGS value fields. This is the most common and powerful method for manufacturing companies.
  2. Using Condition Technique: Similar to SD pricing, you can create rules and access tables to calculate values like commissions, freight, or royalties.
  3. Using a User Exit: For highly complex or custom logic, you can implement custom ABAP code to perform valuation.

Global S4H CLUB will use the Product Cost Estimate method, as it perfectly fits their need for a detailed manufacturing cost breakdown.

2.2. Configuring Valuation Using Product Cost Estimates

Concept: This configuration tells SAP: "At the time of a transaction (like billing), find the product's current standard cost estimate, and map its cost components to these specific value fields."

Prerequisites: Your materials must have a valid, released Standard Cost Estimate. This is typically done via the costing run (CK40N or Fiori equivalent).

Customizing Steps (For Consultants)

  1. Define and Assign a Valuation Strategy:
    • Path: SPRO > Controlling > Profitability Analysis > Master Data > Valuation > Set Up Valuation Using Material Cost Estimate > Define Access to Actual Costing/Material Ledger.
    • How-To: Create a Costing Key, for example, GV01. Within this key, specify that it should read the "Released Standard Cost Estimate." This ensures you always use the current, active standard cost.
  2. Assign the Costing Key to Material Types:
    • Path: SPRO > Controlling > Profitability Analysis > Master Data > Valuation > Set Up Valuation Using Material Cost Estimate > Assign Costing Key to Material Types.
    • How-To: Here, you link your Costing Key GV01 to the material types for which you want this valuation to occur (e.g., FERT for finished goods, HALB for semi-finished goods). You can make this assignment flexible based on other criteria if needed.
  3. Assign Value Fields to Cost Components (The CRITICAL step):
    • Path: SPRO > Controlling > Profitability Analysis > Master Data > Valuation > Set Up Valuation Using Material Cost Estimate > Assign Value Fields for the Cost Components.
    • Fiori App: Assign Value Fields for Cost Components
    • How-To: This is the direct mapping. You will create entries that link your Cost Component Structure GV to your CO-PA value fields.

Costing Key

Cost Component

Value Field (Fixed)

Value Field (Variable)

GV01

10 (Plastics)

(Leave blank if no fixed portion)

VV100

GV01

20 (Rubber)

(Leave blank if no fixed portion)

VV101

GV01

100 (Labor)

VV201 (Fixed Labor)

VV200 (Variable Labor)

...and so on for all components.

...

...

...

Once this is configured, every time a finished good is billed, the system will automatically perform this lookup and breakdown, populating the CO-PA document with a detailed cost of goods sold.

2.3. Characteristic Derivation - Enriching Your Data

Concept: Derivation is the process where the system automatically fills in characteristic values based on other known information. For example, if the system knows the Customer (KNDNR), it can automatically derive the Country (LAND1) and our custom Country Group (WW_CGR) from the customer master data. This automation ensures data is rich and consistent without manual entry.

Derivation rules are processed in a sequence called a strategy.

Customizing Point (For Consultants)

  • Transaction: KEDR
  • Path: SPRO > Controlling > Profitability Analysis > Master Data > Define Characteristic Derivation.

How-To Guide for the "Global S4H CLUB" Derivation Strategy

In transaction KEDR, you will create steps in a specific order.

Step 1: Derivation from Customer Master

  • Type: Derivation rule
  • Source Fields: KNDNR (Customer)
  • Target Fields:
    • KTOKD (Customer Group)
    • LAND1 (Country)
    • VKBUR (Sales Office)
    • VKGRP (Sales Group)
  • Logic: The system automatically proposes reading the master data table KNA1 for these fields. You simply confirm the relationship.

Step 2: Derivation of "Country Group"

  • Type: Derivation rule
  • Description: Determine Country Group from Country
  • Source Field: LAND1 (Country)
  • Target Field: WW_CGR (Country Group)
  • Logic: The system will prompt you to create or maintain a derivation table. Here you will maintain the mapping:

Source: LAND1

Target: WW_CGR

US

NA

CA

NA

MX

LATAM

DE

EMEA

FR

EMEA

CN

APAC

Step 3: Derivation from Material Master

  • Type: Derivation rule
  • Source Field: ARTNR (Product)
  • Target Fields:
    • PRDHA (Product Hierarchy)
    • MVGR1-MVGR5 (Material Groups 1-5)
  • Logic: The system will read the material master tables MARA and MVKE to populate these values.

Step 4: Derivation for Intercompany Sales

  • Type: Derivation rule
  • Source Field: BUKRS (Company Code) and VBUND (Trading Partner)
  • Target Field: A custom characteristic if needed (though VBUND is usually sufficient).
  • Logic: If VBUND is not blank (meaning it's an intercompany transaction), you could move a specific indicator like 'IC' into a custom field for easier reporting selection.

After defining all your steps, save your derivation strategy. It will now execute automatically for every transaction posting to Margin Analysis.

Chapter 3: The End-to-End Process Flow in Action

Theory is great, but let's see how this all comes together in a realistic day-to-day business process for Global S4H CLUB Inc. We will follow a single sales transaction from master data creation to the final profitability analysis.

3.1. Prerequisite: Master Data Setup

Correct and complete master data is the foundation of good reporting.

  1. Create the Finished Product
  • Fiori App: Create Material (MM01)
  • Material: GV-PUMP-01 (High-Pressure Pharmaceutical Pump)
  • Key Fields to Populate:
    • Basic Data: Base Unit of Measure (EA), Material Group.
    • Sales Org Data: Delivering Plant, Tax classifications.
    • MRP Views: MRP Type (PD), Lot Size (EX).
    • Accounting/Costing: Valuation Class (7920), Price Control (S - Standard Price).
    • Crucial for CO-PA: In the "Basic Data" or "Sales" view, assign a Product Hierarchy (e.g., PUMPS / HIGH_PRESSURE / PHARMA).
  1. Create the Customer
  • Fiori App: Manage Business Partner Master Data / Manage Customer Master Data (BP)
  • Customer: GV-CUST-505 (Global Pharma Inc.)
  • Key Fields to Populate:
    • General Data: Address (e.g., Country = US).
    • FI Customer Role: Company Code, Reconciliation Account.
    • Customer Role: Sales Area data (Sales Org, Distr. Channel, Division).
    • Crucial for CO-PA: Set the Customer Group (e.g., Pharma/Biotech).
  1. Create the Manufacturing Cost Estimate
  • Concept: Before you can sell the product, you must determine its standard cost. This involves setting up its Bill of Materials (BOM) and Routing (the manufacturing steps).
  • Process:
    1. Create BOM (CS01): Assign the plastic, rubber, and metal components to GV-PUMP-01.
    2. Create Routing (CA01): Define the labor and machine activities needed to assemble the pump.
    3. Perform Costing Run (CK40N or Edit Product Costing Fiori App): The system calculates the standard cost, rolling up the BOM and Routing costs.
  • Verification (CK13N): Display the cost estimate. You must see the cost broken down by the Cost Components we defined (Plastics, Labor, Overhead, etc.). This breakdown is what will flow to CO-PA.

3.2. The Sales & Distribution (SD) Flow

Now we execute a standard order-to-cash process.

  1. Create Sales Order
  • Fiori App: Create Sales Orders (VA01)
  • Action: Create an order for customer GV-CUST-505 for 10 EA of GV-PUMP-01.
  • Behind the Scenes: At this point, no financial or CO-PA document is generated (as per the Global S4H CLUB design, which doesn't transfer sales orders to CO-PA). The system simply records the future demand.
  1. Create Delivery and Post Goods Issue
  • Fiori App: Manage Outbound Deliveries (VL01N / VL02N)
  • Action: Create a delivery for the sales order and perform the Post Goods Issue (PGI).
  • Behind the Scenes (at PGI): A crucial financial transaction occurs.
    • Dr. Cost of Goods Sold
    • Cr. Inventory - Finished Goods
    • The COGS account is posted to, but the detailed CO-PA posting is still waiting for the billing step.

3.3. Billing - The Moment of Truth for Margin Analysis

This is the climactic step where all our configuration comes to life.

  • Fiori App: Create Billing Documents (VF01)
  • Action: Create a billing document (invoice) for the delivery.
  • Behind the Scenes (at Billing Document Save): A chain reaction is triggered:
    1. SD: The invoice is created.
    2. FI: The main financial document is posted:
      • Dr. Customer A/R
      • Cr. Sales Revenue
    3. CO: The revenue is posted to the relevant controlling objects.
    4. CO-PA (Margin Analysis): A dedicated Profitability Analysis document is created. This is where the magic happens!

Analysis of the CO-PA Document (KE24)

Let's examine the line item that was just created:

Characteristics (The "Who, What, Where"):

  • Product: GV-PUMP-01 (from the sales order)
  • Customer: GV-CUST-505 (from the sales order)
  • Company Code: (from the transaction)
  • Product Hierarchy: PUMPS / HIGH_PRESSURE / PHARMA (Derived from the material master)
  • Customer Group: Pharma/Biotech (Derived from the customer master)
  • Country: US (Derived from the customer master)
  • Country Group: NA (Derived via our derivation rule from US)

Value Fields (The "How Much"):

  • Sales Quantity (VVSQTY): 10 EA
  • Gross Revenue (VVREV): €10,000 (from the SD pricing condition)
  • Sales Deductions (VVDISC): -€500 (from the SD discount condition)
  • Cost - Plastics (VV100): €1,200 (Valuated from the cost estimate component)
  • Cost - Rubber (VV101): €400 (Valuated from the cost estimate component)
  • Cost - Variable Labor (VV200): €800 (Valuated from the cost estimate component)
  • Cost - Fixed Labor (VV201): €350 (Valuated from the cost estimate component)
  • ...and so on for all other cost components.

Instantly, you have a complete profitability picture for this single transaction, with revenue, quantity, and a detailed COGS breakdown, all sliced by multiple analytical dimensions. This is the power of a well-configured Margin Analysis system.

Chapter 4: Planning & Budgeting in Profitability Analysis

Analyzing actuals is only half the story. A complete solution requires the ability to plan and budget future profitability and then compare those plans to actual results. The original "S4H CLUB" project deferred this functionality, but in a modern S/4HANA landscape, it's a critical component.

4.1. The Modern, Strategic Approach: SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)

For S/4HANA, SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) is the strategic, go-forward solution for all financial planning, including profitability planning.

Concept: Instead of using older, transaction-based planning tools within S/4HANA, the process is integrated with the cloud. This provides a superior user experience, more powerful modeling capabilities, and advanced analytics.

The Process Flow:

  1. Data Replication: Actuals data (and master data) from your S/4HANA Margin Analysis is replicated to SAC. This is a standard integration.
  2. Planning in SAC: Planners, such as sales managers, use intuitive, web-based SAC dashboards and input forms to create their sales and margin plans. They can plan at any level of detail (e.g., by customer group and product family).
  3. Advanced Modeling: SAC allows for complex calculations, simulations ("what-if" analysis), and predictive forecasting to assist in the planning process.
  4. Write-Back: Once the plan is finalized and approved in SAC, it is written back to a specific plan/budget version within S/4HANA's core tables.
  5. Plan/Actual Reporting: You can then run reports in S/4HANA Fiori or SAC to compare your planned profitability against the actuals as they occur.

Relevant SAP Best Practice Scope Item: 4_1 (Sales Planning)

4.2. Classic Planning Framework (For Context)

While SAC is the future, S/4HANA still contains the "classic" CO-PA planning framework (KEPM). This tool allows you to define planning levels, create data entry layouts (similar to spreadsheets), and enter plan data directly within the S/4HANA system.

While powerful, its user interface is dated, and it lacks the collaborative and advanced analytical features of SAC. For new implementations, SAC is the highly recommended path.

Chapter 5: Period-End Closing for Margin Analysis

Margin Analysis isn't just about real-time postings from sales. To get a complete profitability picture, you must perform period-end closing activities to allocate costs that aren't directly tied to a single sales transaction.

5.1. Overview of Period-End Activities

Here is a typical checklist of month-end steps for the CO-PA closing process:

  1. Settle production order variances to CO-PA.
  2. Settle internal orders (e.g., marketing campaigns, R&D projects) to CO-PA.
  3. Allocate overhead costs from cost centers (e.g., corporate HR, finance) to CO-PA using assessment cycles.
  4. Perform any top-down distribution of aggregated data.
  5. Reconcile Margin Analysis with the General Ledger.

5.2. Key Processes Explained

  1. Settlement of Production Variances
  • Concept: During production, differences between planned (standard) costs and actual costs create variances (e.g., using more material or labor than planned). These variances must be reflected in your profitability analysis to show the true cost of sales.
  • Transaction: CO88 (Collective Settlement)
  • Process: When you settle a production order, the total variance is posted to FI/CO and also to Margin Analysis. You must configure which value fields will receive these variance postings (e.g., a "Price Variance" value field and a "Quantity Variance" value field). This ensures your product-level profitability is adjusted for manufacturing performance.
  1. Overhead Allocation with Assessment Cycles
  • Concept: Not all costs can be directly traced to a product. For example, the cost of your central marketing department benefits all product lines. An assessment cycle is a rule that allocates these pooled costs to CO-PA segments based on a logical driver (a "tracer").
  • Example: Allocate the total cost of the Marketing cost center ($500,000) to various product hierarchies based on the revenue generated by each.
  • Customizing & Execution:
    • Define Cycle (KSU1):
      • Sender: Marketing Cost Center, Cost Element Group for marketing expenses.
      • Receiver: CO-PA segments defined by characteristics (e.g., Product Hierarchy).
      • Tracer: The basis for allocation (e.g., the VVREV - Revenue value field).
    • Execute Cycle (KSU5): Run the cycle at month-end to perform the allocation. This creates new CO-PA documents that debit the product lines with their share of marketing costs, providing a more complete "fully-costed" margin.

5.3. The Golden Rule: Reconciliation with Financial Accounting

  • Concept: Because Margin Analysis uses its own value field structure, its total profit figure will not match the General Ledger's operating profit by default. Discrepancies can arise from timing differences or configuration gaps. A month-end reconciliation is mandatory to ensure the integrity of your reporting.
  • Tool: The primary tool is the Reconciliation Ledger. You can create a report that compares the G/L account balances for revenue and cost accounts with the sum of the corresponding value fields in Margin Analysis.
  • Transaction: KE5U or dedicated Fiori reporting.
  • Process: Run the report and analyze the differences. For example, if the "Sales Revenue" G/L account shows $10M but the sum of your CO-PA revenue value fields is $9.9M, you have a $100k difference to investigate. This ensures that your detailed profitability view is consistent with your legally reported financial statements.

Chapter 6: Reporting and Analytics - Turning Data into Insight

All this data is useless if you can't access it in a flexible, user-friendly way. S/4HANA has fundamentally changed reporting from static, transaction-based reports to dynamic, real-time analytics.

6.1. The Old World (Still Available): Report Painter

  • Concept: Report Painter (KE30) was the classic tool for building CO-PA reports. It uses a row/column structure where you define "Forms" to structure the report and then generate the final report from the form. The "S4H CLUB" project heavily referenced these custom Z... reports.
  • Relevance Today: While still functional in S/4HANA for compatibility, it is considered a legacy tool. It produces static reports, has a clunky interface, and lacks the drill-down and visualization capabilities of modern tools. It is not recommended for new report development.
  • Example Translation: The requirement "PNL (Socit)" (PNL by Company) would be a simple Report Painter report with Key Figures (Revenue, COGS, Margin) in the rows and Company Code (BUKRS) as the main characteristic in the columns or navigation block.

6.2. The New World: SAP Fiori Analytical Apps

This is the standard and preferred way to analyze profitability data in S/4HANA. These apps leverage the speed of the HANA database to provide real-time, multidimensional analysis directly from the universal journal.

Key Fiori Apps for Margin Analysis:

  • Market Segments - Actuals: This is your primary tool. It's a powerful and flexible "slice-and-dice" report.
    • Features:
      • You can choose from any characteristic in your operating concern to add to your report rows, columns, or filters.
      • You can choose any value field or create on-the-fly calculations (e.g., Margin % = Gross Margin / Net Revenue).
      • Seamless drill-down from an aggregated total down to the original line items (KE24 view) and even to the source billing document or FI journal entry.
      • Instantly switch between chart and table views.
      • Save your personalized report views and share them with colleagues.
  • Profitability Dashboard: Provides a high-level overview of key profitability KPIs with graphical visualizations.
  • Manage KPIs and Reports: A framework that allows key users to define their own analytical queries and build reports without complex technical knowledge.

6.3. Strategic Analytics: SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)

For the most advanced use cases, SAC is the premium tool.

  • Live Connection: SAC can connect live to your S/4HANA system. This means there is no data replication, and you are always analyzing the most current data.
  • Advanced Visualization: Build sophisticated, interactive dashboards that combine profitability data with data from other sources (e.g., CRM, logistics).
  • Predictive Analytics: Use built-in machine learning capabilities to forecast future sales and margins.
  • Enterprise Reporting: Create "board-room ready" reports and stories that can be shared across the organization.

Reporting Strategy for Global S4H CLUB:

  1. Operational Reporting: All day-to-day analysis by product managers, sales reps, and controllers will be done using the Market Segments - Actuals Fiori App.
  2. Executive Dashboards & Planning: High-level dashboards and the entire planning process will be managed in SAP Analytics Cloud.
  3. Legacy Reports: Existing Report Painter reports will be kept for a short time for reference but will be systematically migrated to Fiori or SAC.

Test Scenario 2: Testing Period-End Overhead Allocation

  • Objective: To verify that central overhead costs can be allocated correctly to the product lines based on revenue.
  • Test Data:
    • Sender Cost Center: CC-MKT-EU (European Marketing)
    • Amount to Allocate: €100,000
    • Allocation Basis (Tracer): Gross Revenue
    • Receivers: All profitability segments.

Test Steps:

  1. Post Costs (Prerequisite):
    • App: Post General Journal Entries (FB50)
    • Action: Post a €100,000 expense (e.g., advertising) to the cost center CC-MKT-EU.
  2. Define Assessment Cycle (One-time setup):
    • Transaction: KSU1
    • Action: Create a cycle EU_MKT_ALLOC.
    • Define the sender (CC-MKT-EU) and the receiver (characteristics Product Hierarchy and Company Code).
    • Set the Tracing Factor to be the value field VVREV (Gross Revenue).
  3. Execute Assessment Cycle:
    • Transaction: KSU5
    • Action: Execute the cycle EU_MKT_ALLOC for the current period in "Test Run" mode first.
    • Verification (Test Run): Review the output log. The system should show how it plans to split the €100,000 among the different product hierarchies based on the revenue they generated in the period (including the revenue from Test Scenario 1).
    • Action (Production Run): Once the test run is satisfactory, execute the cycle in production mode (uncheck "Test Run").
  4. Final Verification:
    • App: Market Segments - Actuals
    • Action: Run a report for the product GV-PUMP-02. You should now see a value in the value field you designated for marketing overhead costs. The total profit for this product will be reduced, reflecting a more accurate, fully costed margin.

This concludes the comprehensive guide and test plan. By following these steps, Global S4H CLUB Inc. can successfully implement and leverage SAP S/4HANA Margin Analysis to drive smarter, more profitable business decisions.
